| Parameter | Coal‑fired plant (average) | Nuclear plant (average) |
|-----------|----------------------------|--------------------------|
| Net capacity | **600 MW** (large sub‑critical or super‑critical unit) | **1 200 MW** (single‑reactor press‑urized water reactor, PWR) |
| Capacity factor* | **85 %** (most modern coal plants run close to full load) | **90 %** (modern reactors are slightly higher) |
| Electricity generated over 40 years | 600 MW × 0.85 × 40 yr ≈ 2 040 TWh | 1 200 MW × 0.90 × 40 yr ≈ 4 320 TWh |

\*Capacity factor = actual output ÷ (name‑plate capacity × hours in a year).  

These numbers are **representative averages** used in many life‑cycle assessments (LCAs).  Real plants can be larger or smaller, and the capacity factor can vary with fuel price, grid needs, or regulatory limits.

## 2. Turning “deaths per TWh‑yr” into an absolute death count  

The formula is straightforward:

\[
\text{Expected deaths} = (\text{deaths per TWh‑yr}) \times (\text{total TWh generated over the plant’s life}).
\]

> *Plant accidents*: Very rare for modern plants; the statistical contribution is < 1 % of the total.
